maybe.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: used to say that something may happen or may be true but you are not certain
maybe.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Maybe it’s all just a big misunderstanding.
Maybe they’re right, but maybe not.
You have talent, maybe even genius.
He said he’d finish the work soon – maybe tomorrow.
maybe.translation[0].definitions[0].note: In written English, people often prefer to use perhaps, because it is slightly more formal than maybe:
Perhaps this explains why the figure is so high.
maybe.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: used to reply to a suggestion or idea when either you are not sure if you agree with it, or you do not want to say ‘yes’ or ‘no’
maybe.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: ‘I think Sheila would be an excellent manager.’ ‘Maybe.’
maybe.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: used to show that you are not sure of an amount or number
maybe.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The problems really started maybe two or three years ago.
He looked like he was thirty, maybe thirty-five years old.
maybe.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: used to make a suggestion you are not quite sure about
maybe.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: If the bill doesn’t seem right, maybe you should give them a call.
Maybe I can ride the bicycle and follow you.
